Top Tips: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome
===============

This site is intended for UK healthcare professionals

Welcome to the new home of Guidelines in Practice

Browse our expert articles to support best practice for UK healthcare professionals.

For Primary Care | Top tips

Top Tips: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome
===================================

Dr Roger Henderson | Disclosures | 11 September 2024

### Disclosures

Author(s)

**Dr Roger Henderson**

GP, Dumfries and Galloway

**Dr Roger Henderson Provides Seven Top Tips for Primary Care Practitioners on the Diagnosis and Management of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome**

Continue Reading Below

Read This Article to Learn More About:

*   the causes of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), and when to suspect it
*   approaches to the diagnosis and management of PCOS
*   the treatments available to reduce hyperandrogenism or to induce fertility.

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) was first described in 1935 as Stein‚ÄìLeventhal syndrome by the American gynaecologists Irving Stein and Michael Leventhal, who associated the presence of ovarian cysts with anovulation. PCOS is the most common endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age, and is a well-known cause of infertility and complications in pregnancy. It is associated with a range of health issues, including insulin resistance, the metabolic syndrome, steatotic liver disease, and an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

In the UK, up to one in three women have more than 10 follicles per ovary visible on ultrasound, a condition known as polycystic ovaries; in turn, one in three women with polycystic ovaries will have PCOS. In addition to polycystic ovaries, women with PCOS may have one or more of a group of characteristic features‚Äîincluding acne, male-pattern baldness, hirsutism, amenorrhoea, and oligomenorrhoea‚Äîand raised serum levels of testosterone and/or luteinising hormone (LH).

### The Burden of PCOS

The burden of PCOS on women affected by it can be significant. At one time, it was considered to be mainly a reproductive condition, but it is now accepted that women with PCOS are at high risk of metabolic disorders, such as obesity and type 2 diabetes. Furthermore, women with PCOS have been shown to have an increased risk of psychological morbidity, asthma, and migraine.

### Guidance on PCOS

Although no NICE Guideline has been published specifically on PCOS, the condition is covered in NICE Clinical Guideline 156, _Fertility problems: assessment and treatment_, and further guidance on the symptoms, diagnosis, and management of PCOS is available from other sources, including:

*   the _International evidence-based guideline for the assessment and management of polycystic ovary syndrome 2023_
    *   summary of recommendations
    *   full guidance
*   the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology (ESHRE)/American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) Workshop Group
*   the Androgen Excess Society
*   the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
*   the _British National Formulary._

This article provides seven top tips for primary care practitioners on the causes of PCOS and when to suspect it, approaches to its diagnosis and management, and best practice regarding its treatment.

1\. Be Aware That the Causes of PCOS Remain Unclear
---------------------------------------------------

PCOS is reportedly present in around 5‚Äì15% of women of reproductive age. However, its prevalence rises to as much as 20% when the diagnostic criteria proposed by the ESHRE/ASRM-Sponsored PCOS Consensus Workshop Group (termed the ‚Äò2003 Rotterdam Criteria‚Äô) are used.

The causes of PCOS remain unclear, but the condition is multifactorial and appears to be inherited as a common, complex genetic disorder. Insulin resistance is found in approximately 65‚Äì80% of women with PCOS, independent of obesity, and is worsened by excess weight triggered by the condition. Levels of LH are increased in nearly 40% of women with PCOS because of increased production from the anterior pituitary gland. Theca cells in the ovaries produce excess androgens because of hyperinsulinaemia or increased serum levels of LH, and women with PCOS may also have increased serum oestrogen levels. As a result of continued exposure to oestrogen unopposed by progesterone, the endometrium may become hyperplastic, and testosterone is also converted to oestrogen in peripheral fat.

2\. Recognise That no Formal Classification System for PCOS Currently Exists
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Although no formal classification system currently exists for PCOS, proposals have been made to establish one.

Box 1: Phenotypes of PCOS

*   **Mild PCOS (16% of women with PCOS)**‚Äîcharacterised by irregular periods, polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, mildly raised androgen concentrations, and normal insulin concentrations
*   **Ovulatory PCOS (16% of women with PCOS)**‚Äîcharacterised by normal periods, polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, high androgen concentrations, and increased insulin concentrations
*   **Hyperandrogenism and chronic anovulation (7% of women with PCOS)**‚Äîcharacterised by irregular periods, normal ovaries on ultrasound, high androgen concentrations, and increased insulin concentrations; this phenotype has potential long-term risks
*   **Severe PCOS (61% of women with PCOS)**‚Äîcharacterised by irregular periods, polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, high androgen concentrations, and increased insulin concentrations; this phenotype also has potential long-term risks.

Current guidance recommends that PCOS should be diagnosed using the international evidence-based guideline criteria, which build on the consensus-based 2003 Rotterdam criteria. These require the presence of two of the following to diagnose PCOS:

*   clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
*   ovulatory dysfunction
*   polycystic ovaries on ultrasound.

Alternatively, assessment of serum anti-M√ºllerian hormone (AMH) can now be used instead of ultrasound, provided that other aetiologies are also excluded. Importantly, when irregular menstrual cycles and hyperandrogenism are present, diagnosis is now simplified, and ultrasound or AMH are not required. In adolescents, both hyperandrogenism and ovulatory dysfunction are required, with ultrasound and AMH not recommended because of poor specificity. Note that, according to the 2003 Rotterdam criteria, a diagnosis of PCOS can only be made when other causes have been ruled out, such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, androgen-secreting tumours, or Cushing‚Äôs syndrome.

The international evidence-based guideline criteria differ slightly from those issued in 2006 by the Androgen Excess Society, which require all of the following to be present for a diagnosis of PCOS to be made:

*   hyperandrogenism‚Äîhirsutism and/or hyperandrogenaemia
*   ovarian dysfunction‚Äîoligo-ovulation or anovulation and/or polycystic ovaries
*   exclusion of other androgen excess or related disorders.

3\. Know That a Diagnosis of PCOS is One of Exclusion
-----------------------------------------------------

Common features of PCOS include hirsutism (present in 60% of women), acne (present in 15‚Äì25%), scalp hair loss or male-pattern baldness (present in 5%), irregular and infrequent periods, weight gain or difficulty losing weight, and infertility. Acanthosis nigricans may also be present, especially in obese women with PCOS, and is thought to be linked to insulin resistance. Less commonly, there may be deepening of the voice, clitoromegaly, and increased muscle mass.

Symptoms typically begin at the time of puberty and, in younger women, may be difficult to distinguish from the irregular menses that often occur in the first year after menarche. Although the diagnostic criteria for PCOS during adolescence are controversial, guidelines recommend that both ovulatory dysfunction and hyperandrogenism must be present to diagnose PCOS in adolescents.

Body mass index (BMI) and waist-to-height ratio should be checked in all women with PCOS, as 40‚Äì80% of women with the syndrome are overweight or obese, with central obesity predominating (a waist-to-hip ratio of at least 0.85, or waist circumference of at least 88 cm). Blood pressure should also be monitored, as women with PCOS may have elevated blood pressure.

Differential diagnoses of PCOS are presented in Box 2.

Box 2: Differential Diagnoses of PCOS

*   Hypothyroidism
*   Hyperprolactinaemia
*   Acromegaly
*   Cushing‚Äôs syndrome and androgen-secreting tumours
*   Iatrogenic side effects from medication causing hirsutism such as danazol, high-dose corticosteroids, ciclosporin, and phenytoin.

4\. Understand That Investigations for PCOS Consist of Endocrine Tests and Ovarian Imaging
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The three main endocrine abnormalities in PCOS are:

*   elevated serum LH levels, with normal serum follicle-stimulating hormone levels
*   elevated free testosterone levels (a combination of increased testosterone production and reduced sex hormone-binding globulin), and
*   insulin resistance with compensatory hyperinsulinaemia.

Women with PCOS typically have a serum testosterone level above 2.5 nmol/l and a serum LH level above 10 IU/l. If the total testosterone level is above 5 nmol/l, always check for other possible causes of androgen hypersecretion, such as androgen-secreting adrenal or ovarian tumours, or nonclassical congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Fasting plasma glucose and/or glycated haemoglobin are useful for assessing insulin resistance. Although these tests are less accurate than the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), they are acceptable alternatives if an OGTT cannot be performed. A lipid profile should also be obtained to evaluate cardiovascular risk. Prolactin testing is recommended to exclude hyperprolactinaemia, which may present with oligo-ovulation or anovulation. In addition, thyroid function tests are important because thyroid dysfunction may present with oligo-ovulation or anovulation, or irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding, and weight gain.

Ultrasound is used to assess for the presence of polycystic ovarian morphology, unless the diagnosis of PCOS is obvious on clinical and biochemical grounds. When appropriate, transvaginal ultrasound provides higher-resolution images of the ovaries compared with transabdominal ultrasound. Remember that the presence of polycystic ovaries alone does not confirm the diagnosis. Ultrasound should not be used to diagnose PCOS in adolescents and, in adults, it should ideally be done in the early follicular phase (days 3‚Äì5) after a spontaneous or progestin-withdrawal-induced menstruation. If menstrual bleeding is infrequent or reduced, ultrasound can be done at any time. If endometrial thickening is found on imaging, an endometrial biopsy is indicated to determine whether endometrial hyperplasia or cancer is present.

5\. Inform Women About Possible Long-term Risks and Lifestyle Interventions
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Healthcare professionals should inform women with PCOS about the potential long-term health risks that are associated with the syndrome. Obesity, dyslipidaemia, and insulin resistance all increase cardiovascular risk, and screening should be offered for impaired glucose tolerance and diabetes.

Women diagnosed with PCOS should be advised about weight loss and exercise, as weight loss improves fertility and pregnancy outcomes, psychological symptoms, and metabolic risk‚Äîeven if BMI remains raised. A low-glycaemic-index diet may be helpful in managing PCOS. Hypertension should be treated in the usual way, although there is no rationale for the routine use of statins in women with PCOS outside normal guidelines.

6\. Consider the Range of Available Treatments
----------------------------------------------

No single treatment can reverse the hormonal changes of PCOS or address all of its clinical features; therefore, medical management should be tailored to each individual‚Äôs specific symptoms. The combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP) is one of the treatments often considered, provided that there are no contraindications. It should be prescribed with the usual guidance about risks, side effects, and potential drug interactions. However, COCPs containing 35 mcg ethinyloestradiol and cyproterone acetate should not be used as a first-line treatment for PCOS because of their potential adverse effects, which include venous thromboembolism.

If acne is a significant issue, topical retinoids or antibiotics and/or oral antibiotics can be prescribed as appropriate. If hirsutism is present, hair removal methods, such as waxing or shaving, should be discussed. In general, the oral contraceptive pill is more effective for acne than for hirsutism in PCOS.

In women with prolonged amenorrhoea or abnormal vaginal bleeding, a cyclical progestogen should be prescribed to induce a withdrawal bleed, followed by a referral for a transvaginal ultrasound to assess endometrial thickness. If endometrial thickening is present, clinicians should refer women for endometrial sampling to exclude endometrial hyperplasia or cancer. If the endometrium is normal, women should be advised on treatment to prevent endometrial hyperplasia and its associated risks. These options include a low-dose COCP, a cyclical progestogen, or a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (LNG-IUD). If a woman is unwilling to take cyclical hormone treatment or use the LNG-IUD, specialist advice should be sought, as regular ultrasound is required to assess endometrial thickness.

If a woman with PCOS presents with infertility and wishes to conceive, NICE Clinical Guideline 156, _Fertility problems: assessment and treatment_, recommends that‚Äîafter weight loss (when indicated) and a full fertility work-up‚Äîtreatment should include clomifene citrate, metformin, or a combination of both. Clomifene citrate appears to be preferable to metformin for ovulation induction in women with obesity and PCOS.

7\. Keep in Mind That Metformin is Used Off Label to Treat PCOS
---------------------------------------------------------------

In primary care, when considering starting metformin in women with PCOS but without diabetes, clinicians should consider seeking specialist advice, as metformin is not currently licensed for this indication. The _International evidence-based guideline for the assessment and management of PCOS 2023_, issued by the International PCOS Network, makes the following recommendations on the use of metformin for indications not relating to fertility:

*   in addition to lifestyle interventions, metformin alone should be considered in women with a BMI greater than or equal to 25 kg/m2 for anthropometric and metabolic outcomes, including insulin resistance, glucose, and lipid profiles
*   in combination with a COCP, metformin may be most beneficial in high metabolic risk groups, including women with a BMI greater than 30 kg/m¬≤, diabetes risk factors, and/or impaired glucose tolerance, and/or who have a high-risk ethnic background.

If metformin is initiated in primary care, off-label use should be explained alongside the fact that adverse effects may occur, such as gastrointestinal symptoms and reduced vitamin B12 levels.

Summary
-------

PCOS is the most common endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age, as well as being a major cause of infertility and pregnancy complications. It gives rise to symptoms of hyperandrogenism, the presence of hyperandrogenaemia, oligo-ovulation or anovulation, and polycystic ovarian morphology on ultrasound. It is strongly associated with complications including insulin resistance, the metabolic syndrome, steatotic liver disease, and an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes. The main aims of treatment are to reduce hyperandrogenism and to induce fertility. Primary care doctors are in an ideal position to identify women with symptoms and signs of PCOS early, and by doing so help to reduce the significant burden that PCOS can place on people with the condition.

Key Points 

*   PCOS is the most common endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age, and a well-known cause of infertility and pregnancy complications
*   In the UK, up to one in three women have more than 10 follicles per ovary visible on ultrasound (polycystic ovaries), and one in three women with polycystic ovaries will have PCOS
*   PCOS is defined as the presence of polycystic ovaries together with one or more characteristic features, including acne, male-pattern baldness, hirsutism, amenorrhoea, and oligomenorrhoea, and raised serum levels of testosterone and/or LH
*   The cause of PCOS is unclear, but it is multifactorial and inherited as a common, complex genetic disorder
*   Insulin resistance is found in approximately 65‚Äì80% of women with PCOS, independent of obesity, and is exacerbated by excess weight triggered by the condition
*   LH levels are increased in nearly 40% of women with PCOS because of increased production from the anterior pituitary gland
*   Women with PCOS may also have increased serum oestrogen and testosterone levels
*   Investigations for PCOS consist of endocrine tests and ovarian imaging
*   Ultrasound is used to assess the presence of polycystic ovarian morphology, unless the diagnosis of PCOS is obvious on clinical and biochemical grounds
*   No single treatment can reverse the hormonal changes of PCOS or address all of its clinical features, so medical management should be tailored to each individual‚Äôs symptoms
*   Metformin, in combination with a combined oral contraceptive pill, may offer greater benefit in high metabolic risk groups, including women with a BMI >30 kg/m¬≤, diabetes risk factors, and/or impaired glucose tolerance, and/or from high-risk ethnic groups
*   If metformin is initiated in primary care, off-label use should be explained alongside the fact that adverse effects may occur, such as gastrointestinal symptoms and reduced vitamin B12 levels.

Note: At the time of publication (September 2024), some of the treatments discussed in this article did not have UK marketing authorisation for the indications discussed. Prescribers should refer to the individual summaries of product characteristics for further information and recommendations regarding the use of pharmacological therapies. For off-licence use of medicines, the prescriber should follow relevant professional guidance, taking full responsibility for the decision. Informed consent should be obtained and documented. See the General Medical Council‚Äôs _Good practice in prescribing and managing medicines and devices_ for further information.

Note: This issue only affects those of the female sex and so the terms woman/women and the pronouns she/her have been used throughout this article. Sensitivity should be used when your patient‚Äôs gender does not match their biological sex, including using the patient‚Äôs preferred pronouns.

**Implementation Actions for ICSs**

**written by Dr David Jenner, GP, Cullompton, Devon**

The following implementation actions are designed to support ICSs with the challenges involved in implementing new guidance at a system level. Our aim is to help you to consider how to deliver improvements to healthcare within the available resources.

*   **Review** local care pathways for the investigation and management of PCOS to ensure that they include screening for comorbidities like type 2 diabetes
*   **Update** local care pathways in line with the latest guidance, with triggers for referral to specialist care and required investigations
*   **Consider** creating a specific ‚Äòsuspected PCOS‚Äô blood test request group in pathology request systems to ensure that the required set of biochemical tests are performed
*   **Identify** on- and off-label therapies in formularies to assist in symptom management and endometrial protection
*   **Make sure** that clear guidance is available to ensure endometrial protection because of the increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer
*   **Signpost** to patient-centred resources to help patients understand PCOS and encourage weight loss and self-help.

ICS=integrated care system; PCOS=polycystic ovary syndrome

Input:
Once-weekly dose of insulin efsitora alfa delivers A1C reduction consistent with the most advanced daily insulin in people with type 2 diabetes
===============================================================================================================================================

News provided by

Eli Lilly and Company Sep 10, 2024, 11:18 ET

Share this article

In QWINT-2, efsitora helped adults na√Øve to insulin therapy currently using and not using GLP-1 receptor agonists achieve an A1C below 7%

Detailed results were published in The New England Journal of Medicine and simultaneously presented at the European Association for the Study of Diabetes (EASD) Annual Meeting 2024

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Eli Lilly and Company (NYSE: LLY) today announced detailed results from the QWINT-2 phase 3 trial evaluating once-weekly insulin efsitora alfa (efsitora) compared to once-daily insulin degludec in adults with type 2 diabetes using insulin for the first time (insulin na√Øve). The data were published in The New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) and simultaneously presented today at the European Association for the Study of Diabetes (EASD) Annual Meeting 2024.

In the trial, efsitora met the primary endpoint of non-inferior A1C reduction. For the efficacy estimand, efsitora reduced A1C by 1.34% compared to 1.26% for insulin degludec resulting in an A1C of 6.87% and 6.95% respectively at 52 weeks.

Additionally, participants taking efsitora achieved 45 minutes more time in range per day, a key secondary endpoint, without additional time in hypoglycemia (glucose <54 mg/dL) in comparison to insulin degludec for the efficacy estimand.

"Traditionally, basal insulins are dosed once a day ‚Äî a treatment schedule that can make compliance difficult for a significant portion of people living with type 2 diabetes," said Carol Wysham, M.D., clinical professor of medicine at the University of Washington School of Medicine. "Efsitora has the potential to address treatment burden and improve adherence ‚Äî all while lowering A1C. These results can make a significant impact for people living with type 2 diabetes looking for a once-weekly option that provides similar outcomes as daily insulins."

**Full Results**

**QWINT-2 Study: Primary and Secondary Endpoints**

Efficacy Estimand

Treatment-Regimen Estimand

Primary Endpoint ‚Äì A1C Reduction (Resulting A1C) at Week 52

Efsitora

-1.34% (6.87%)

-1.26% (6.97%)

Degludec

-1.26% (6.95%)

-1.17% (7.05%)

Secondary Endpoint ‚Äì A1C Reduction in Participants using GLP-1s (Resulting A1C) at Week 52

Efsitora

-1.30% (6.90%)

-1.26% (6.96%)

Degludec

-1.28% (6.92%)

-1.19% (7.02%)

Secondary Endpoint ‚Äì A1C Reduction in Participants not using GLP-1s (Resulting A1C) at Week 52

Efsitora

-1.38% (6.85%)

-1.26% (6.97%)

-1.23% (6.99%)

Secondary Endpoint ‚Äì Percent Time in Range During the 4 Weeks Prior to Week 52

Efsitora

68.86%

Degludec

65.75%

61.18%

"For the past century, we've been searching for the next scientific breakthrough that would alleviate the complexity that comes with starting insulin treatment," said Jeff Emmick, M.D., Ph.D., senior vice president, product development, Lilly. "With these results, we believe we're headed towards a future where people with type 2 diabetes who use basal insulin can achieve their desired results with a simple treatment option like efsitora."

In the trial, efsitora demonstrated a safety profile similar to daily insulins. There were no severe hypoglycemic events reported during treatment with efsitora compared to six reported with insulin degludec. Overall hypoglycemia rates in the study were low, with estimated combined rates of severe or clinically significant (blood glucose <54 mg/dL) hypoglycemic events per patient-year of exposure of 0.58 with efsitora vs. 0.45 with insulin degludec. Estimated combined rates of severe or clinically significant nocturnal hypoglycemic events per patient-year of exposure were 0.08 with both efsitora and insulin degludec. Additionally, rates of hypoglycemia were similar among people currently using GLP-1s and those not using GLP-1s. Adverse events were similar between treatment groups in the trial.

Detailed results for QWINT-5 are also being presented at EASD and simultaneously published in The Lancet.

**About the QWINT clinical trial program**  
The QWINT phase 3 global clinical development program for insulin efsitora alfa (efsitora) in diabetes began in 2022 and has enrolled more than 4,000 people living with type 1 or type 2 diabetes across five global registration studies.

QWINT-2 (NCT05362058) was a parallel-design, open-label, treat-to-target, randomized controlled clinical trial comparing the efficacy and safety of efsitora as a once-weekly basal insulin to insulin degludec for 52 weeks in insulin-na√Øve adults with type 2 diabetes. The trial randomized 928 participants across the U.S., Brazil, Canada, China, Czechia (Czech Republic), Germany, Greece, Japan, Korea, Mexico and Puerto Rico to receive efsitora once weekly or insulin degludec once daily administered subcutaneously. The primary objective of the trial was to demonstrate non-inferiority in reducing A1C at week 52 with efsitora compared to insulin degludec. The trial was also designed to assess efficacy and safety for patients using and not using GLP-1 receptor agonists.

**About insulin efsitora alfa**  
Insulin efsitora alfa (efsitora) is a once-weekly basal insulin, a fusion protein that combines a novel single-chain variant of insulin with a human IgG2 Fc domain. It is specifically designed for once-weekly subcutaneous administration, and with its low peak-to-trough ratio, it has the potential to provide more stable glucose levels (less glucose variability) throughout the week. Efsitora is in phase 3 development for adults with type 1 and 2 diabetes.

**About Lilly**  
Lilly is a medicine company turning science into healing to make life better for people around the world. We've been pioneering life-changing discoveries for nearly 150 years, and today our medicines help more than 51 million people across the globe. Harnessing the power of biotechnology, chemistry and genetic medicine, our scientists are urgently advancing new discoveries to solve some of the world's most significant health challenges: redefining diabetes care; treating obesity and curtailing its most devastating long-term effects; advancing the fight against Alzheimer's disease; providing solutions to some of the most debilitating immune system disorders; and transforming the most difficult-to-treat cancers into manageable diseases. With each step toward a healthier world, we're motivated by one thing: making life better for millions more people. That includes delivering innovative clinical trials that reflect the diversity of our world and working to ensure our medicines are accessible and affordable. To learn more, visit Lilly.com and Lilly.com/news, or follow us on Facebook, Instagram and LinkedIn. P-LLY

**Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Statements**  
This press release contains forward-looking statements (as that term is defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995), including statements about insulin efsitora alfa as a potential treatment for people with type 2 diabetes and the timeline for future readouts, presentations, and other milestones relating to insulin efsitora alfa and its clinical trials, and reflects Lilly's current beliefs and expectations. However, as with any pharmaceutical product, there are substantial risks and uncertainties in the process of drug research, development, and commercialization. Among other things, there is no guarantee that planned or ongoing studies will be completed as planned, that future study results will be consistent with study results to date, that insulin efsitora alfa will prove to be a safe and effective treatment for type 2 diabetes, that insulin efsitora alfa will receive regulatory approval, or that Lilly will execute its strategy as expected. For further discussion of these and other risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ from Lilly's expectations, see Lilly's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filings with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. Except as required by law, Lilly undertakes no duty to update forward-looking statements to reflect events after the date of this release.

2 95% CI for treatment difference (-0.22% to 0.06%).  
3 From a baseline A1C of 8.21% for efsitora and 8.23% for insulin degludec.  
4 Blood glucose 70-180 mg/dL.  
5 Treatment-regimen estimand represents the efficacy irrespective of adherence to the investigational medicine or introduction of rescue therapy for persistent severe hyperglycemia.  
6 From a baseline A1C of 8.21% for efsitora and 8.24% for insulin degludec.  
7 95% CI for treatment difference (-0.22% to 0.04%).

Input:
FDA Grants Orphan Drug Designation to ABD-147 in Neuroendocrine Carcinoma
=========================================================================

September 10, 2024

By [Sabrina Serani](https://www.targetedonc.com/authors/sabrina-serani)

Fact checked by [Jordyn Sava](https://www.targetedonc.com/authors/jordyn-sava)

_News_

_Article_

[FDA Briefs|September 2024 Brief](https://www.targetedonc.com/fda-briefs/september-2024-brief)

The next-generation radiopharmaceutical ABD-147 was previously granted FDA fast track designation in extensive-stage small cell lung cancer.

ABD-147, a next-generation precision radiopharmaceutical, has been granted orphan drug designation by the FDA for the treatment of neuroendocrine carcinoma.

With this designation, Abdera Therapeutics, the sponsor, can be eligible for incentives like tax credits for clinical trials, exemption from user fees, and a potential 7 years of market exclusivity.

‚ÄúNeuroendocrine carcinomas, including SCLC and LCNEC, are aggressive and challenging to treat effectively with current systemic therapies,‚Äù said Philippe Bishop, MD, chief medical officer of Abdera Therapeutics, in a press release. ‚ÄúBy delivering a potent radioisotope to neuroendocrine tumors expressing DLL3 with custom-engineered pharmacokinetic properties, we believe ABD-147 has the potential to become a best-in-class DLL3-targeting treatment for aggressive neuroendocrine tumors.‚Äù

In July 2024, the FDA also granted fast track designation to ABD-147 in extensive-stage SCLC. The fast track designation is intended to facilitate the development and review of drugs that treat serious conditions and fill unmet needs. The designation provides the sponsor with more frequent communication with the FDA as well as eligibility for accelerated approval and priority review.

This year, Abdera will begin a phase 1, first-in-human study evaluating ABD-147 in LCNEC and SCLC that has been previously treated with platinum-based therapy.

ABD-147 is designed to deliver actininum-225 to DLL3-expressing tumors. DLL3 is upregulated in some high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas, including SCLC, while it is typically absent on the surface of nonmalignant cells, making it an attractive target for radiotherapy.

###### REFERENCES:

###### 1. Abdera Therapeutics announces FDA orphan drug designation for ABD-147 for the treatment of neuroendocrine carcinoma. News release. Abdera Therapeutics. September 5, 2024. Accessed September 10, 2024. [https://tinyurl.com/fccse5a7](https://tinyurl.com/fccse5a7)

###### 2. Abdera Therapeutics announces FDA fast track designation for ABD-147, a next-generation precision radiopharmaceutical therapy, for the treatment of patients with extensive-stage small cell lung cancer. News release. Abdera Therapeutics. June 27, 2024. Accessed September 10, 2024. [https://tinyurl.com/3k2y8ece](https://tinyurl.com/3k2y8ece)

- A newly published phase 3 trial, BETTER B, has found that mirtazapine does not significantly reduce breathlessness in adults with COPD or interstitial lung disease. Despite its previous promise, this study urges healthcare professionals to rethink off-label prescribing of antidepressants for this purpose.

- üòØ Participants were randomized into mirtazapine and placebo groups, and after 56 days of treatment, results showed no difference in the severity of breathlessness between the groups: adjusted mean score difference was 0.105 (P = 0.69).

As our understanding of symptom management evolves, how can we safely explore treatment options beyond our traditional boundaries? ü§î

Mirtazapine Fails to Ease Breathlessness in New Study Despite Previous Hopes
===============================================================================

September 10, 2024

By Chelsie Derman

News

Article

A phase 3 trial found mirtazapine ineffective in reducing breathlessness in respiratory disease patients, urging caution with off-label antidepressant use.

Mirtazapine may have previously shown promise in the modulation of respiratory sensation, but a new phase 3 study revealed this antidepressant does not improve breathlessness in patients with respiratory disease.

‚ÄúDespite being a widespread issue, we still don‚Äôt have effective treatments available,‚Äù said first author Irene Higginson, FFPHM, from King‚Äôs College London, in a statement. ‚ÄúAs such, many doctors turn to off-label prescribing, trying to help their patients.‚Äù

It has been suggested antidepressants may modulate respiratory sensation even in the absence of a mood disorder by increasing serotonin levels in respiratory control and other centers such as the amygdala. After all, mirtazapine reduces panic, and it is known panic often comes with episodes of severe breathlessness.

Although an earlier trial found sertraline did not affect chronic breathlessness, Higginson and colleagues conducted a study to evaluate whether another antidepressant‚Äîmirtazapine‚Äîwas effective at reducing breathlessness. Findings of BETTER B, an international, multicenter, phase 3, parallel-group, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled pragmatic trial, were presented at the ERS Congress in Vienna. The BETTER B trial was conducted in 16 centers in Australia, Germany, Ireland, Italy, New Zealand, Poland, and the UK and was informed by a feasibility trial published in 2020.

The primary outcome was the reduction of self-reported worst breathlessness over the past 24 hours, measured at day 56, compared with placebo. Secondary outcomes included the worst breathlessness at various times, average breathlessness, number and duration of breathlessness episodes, and physical and emotional aspects of breathlessness such as dyspnea, fatigue, emotional function, and quality life. Another secondary outcome was symptoms and concerns evaluated by the integrated palliative care outcome scale.

The sample, screened between February 4, 2021, and March 28, 2024, were aged ‚â• 18 years (mean age: 74 years); had either COPD, interstitial lung diseases, or both; and were grade 3 or 4 of the modified Medical Research Council breathlessness scale. All participants were stable for the previous 2 weeks before baseline and on optimal treatment for reversible causes of breathlessness, determined by the referring clinician and best clinical guidance. People were excluded from the study if they had existing use of antidepressants or serotonergic active substances, had known contraindications to mirtazapine, or received an Australia-modified Karnofsky Performance Scale score of ‚â§ 40 which indicates they are in bed ‚â• 50% of the time.

Participants (n = 225) were randomized 1:1 to receive either mirtazapine or placebo daily for 56 days. They had a dose of 15 mg orally for the first 14 days. After that, there were 2 assessments for dose escalations, at days 14 and 28. Participants had their dose increased to 30 mg at day 14 and to 45 mg at day 28 if they did not show improvement in their breathlessness, measured using the Numerical Rating Scale over the previous 24 hours. At the end of day 56, the dose was tapered and discontinued.

Investigators assessed participants at baseline and at days 7, 14, 28, 56, and 7 days after completing the trial to assess for safety and toxicity of the treatment. Participants were called 180 days from baseline by phone, video call, or mail to complete the last self-reported questionnaire. Caregivers completed questionnaires at days 28, 56, and 180.

At day 14, nearly half (48%) of participants on mirtazapine had escalation, compared with 53% on placebo. At day 28, 35% participants on mirtazapine had escalation, which was slightly less than those on placebo (36%).

At day 56, 3 participants on mirtazapine and 2 on placebo died. At day 180, the number of people who died was 6% in the mirtazapine arm and 10% in the placebo arm. In total, 5 participants were lost to follow-up, with 3% in the mirtazapine arm and 2% in the placebo arm.

Investigators did not observe a difference in worst breathlessness score day 56 between mirtazapine and placebo (difference in adjusted mean score [mirtazapine minus placebo], 0.105; 95% confidence interval [CI], -0.407 to 0.618; P = .69). The sensitivity analysis, to account for missing data, also found no evidence of a difference between treatment arms (difference in adjusted mean score; 0.232; 95% CI, -9.308 to 0.773; P = .40). Secondary outcomes also demonstrated no differences between the arms in terms of measures of breathlessness, overall palliative symptoms, average breathlessness score, chronic respiratory questionnaire subscales, anxiety and depression, number and duration of breathlessness, Australia-modified Karnofsky performance scale, and generalized-efficacy scale.

The study reported 215 adverse events in 64% participants on mirtazapine and 40% on placebo, with the most common ones in the mirtazapine arm being dry mouth, somnolence, fatigue, and sedation. Serious adverse events occurred in 5% of participants on mirtazapine and 6% on placebo.

‚ÄúThis new trial concludes that mirtazapine is not recommended for the treatment of breathlessness, that the use of unlicensed medicines should be approached with caution and that it‚Äôs crucial to subject medicines in palliative care to rigorous trials,‚Äù Higginson said.

References

1. Higginson, I, Brown, S, Oluyase, A, et al. Mirtazapine to alleviate severe breathlessness in patients with COPD or interstitial lung diseases (BETTER-B): an international, multicentre, double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled, phase 3 mixed-method trial. The Lancet Respiratory Medicine. 2024. [https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanres/article/PIIS2213-2600(24)00187-5/fulltext](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanres/article/PIIS2213-2600/(24/)00187-5/fulltext). Accessed September 10, 2024.
2. Drugs prescribed off-label may do more harm than good. EurekAlert! September 9, 2024. [https://www.eurekalert.org/news-releases/1056889](https://www.eurekalert.org/news-releases/1056889). Accessed September 10, 2024.

Have you considered the potential role of diabetes medication in HIV treatment? ü§î 

- New research from the Universit√© de Montr√©al reveals that metformin, a drug primarily used for type 2 diabetes, may play a crucial role in managing HIV by targeting immune reservoirs. 
- After three months of metformin usage, patients exhibited reduced chronic inflammation and improved immunity, thanks to inhibition of HIV replication via the mTOR pathway. 
- Surprisingly, metformin demonstrated a dual effect by both increasing HIV-infected cells and preventing the virus from escaping. This nuanced interaction highlights the complexity of viral reservoirs and immune response. 
- The study found metformin enhances the BST2 protein levels, which helps the immune system recognize and eliminate HIV-infected cells more effectively through neutralizing antibodies. 
- This encourages the application of a revised "shock-and-kill" strategy for HIV eradication, suggesting that metformin could reactivate viral reservoirs in conjunction with existing therapeutic antibodies. 

As researchers embark on clinical trials to explore these findings further, how might this reshape our understanding of treatment strategies for patients with HIV?  

For more insights, read the full study here: https://medicalxpress.com/news/2024-09-diabetes-drug-immune-reservoirs-hiv.html

Input:
Diabetes drug helps the immune system recognize reservoirs of HIV, study discovers
==================================================================================

by Bruno Geoffroy, University of Montreal Hospital Research Centre

Metformin, a drug used to treat type 2 diabetes, could help deplete the viral reservoir and eliminate it entirely in people living with HIV who receive antiretroviral therapy, Canadian researchers say in a new study.

In 2021, a team led by immunologist Petronela Ancuta of Universit√© de Montr√©al's affiliated hospital research center, the CRCHUM, showed that metformin, when taken for three months, improved patients' immunity and reduced the chronic inflammation usually associated with complications such as cardiovascular disease.

One reason these benefits are so effective is that metformin inhibits the activity of the mTOR (mechanistic target of rapamycin) molecule, which in turn slows down HIV replication in the cells of patients infected with the virus.

In the journal _iScience_, Ancuta and her student Augustine Fert, the study's first author and a recent Ph.D. holder, go further. They studied the molecular mechanisms of action of metformin on HIV replication in CD4 T lymphocytes, which are immune system cells that provide shelter for the virus.

In these reservoirs, HIV keeps on replicating, which contributes to the chronic inflammation by constantly activating the immune system.

"The results of our in vitro tests on cells from people living with HIV and treated with antiretroviral therapy caught us off guard at first," said Ancuta. "They were a bit surprising. We discovered that metformin had both a proviral and an antiviral effect. The drug helped boost the number of HIV-infected cells, while also stopping the virus from escaping the cell."

Antibodies to the rescue
------------------------

Another benefit of metformin is that it overexpresses the BST2 protein, which acts as a kind of glue to keep virions clinging to the surface of HIV-infected cells. The immune system then spots them and can target them with antibodies.

"Together with my colleague Andr√©s Finzi, we tested the ability of several broad-spectrum neutralizing anti-HIV antibodies to recognize viral reservoir cells after metformin exposure in vitro," said Ancuta. "Some of them recognized the virus very well, suggesting their ability to attract and trigger the destruction of infected cells by NK cells through a process of cellular cytotoxicity."

These recent scientific advances mean that the "shock-and-kill" eradication strategy, often used in the fight against HIV, can be foreseen in a different way, she added.

"In people living with HIV and treated with antiretroviral therapy, we could use metformin to reactivate the reservoir cells responsible for viral replication upon treatment interruption, in combination with antibodies that are already used clinically and well tolerated. These antibodies can then detect the rare infected cells and eliminate them."

In the next phase of her research, Ancuta plans to launch a clinical trial to validate her in vitro research results, in collaboration with Finzi and their CRCHUM colleague Nicolas Chomont, and Jean-Pierre Routy of the McGill University Health Center Research Institute.

Before she can move forward with this strategy, she will test it in preclinical models.

**More information:** Augustine Fert et al, Metformin facilitates viral reservoir reactivation and their recognition by anti-HIV-1 envelope antibodies, _iScience_ (2024). DOI: 10.1016/j.isci.2024.110670

**Journal information:** _iScience_

Provided by University of Montreal Hospital Research Centre

**Citation**: Diabetes drug helps the immune system recognize reservoirs of HIV, study discovers (2024, September 10) retrieved 11 September 2024 from https://medicalxpress.com/news/2024-09-diabetes-drug-immune-reservoirs-hiv.html

- A retrospective analysis involving 90 patients revealed that both magnesium valproate and lamotrigine significantly improved neuropsychiatric outcomes compared to olanzapine. After three weeks, both adjunctive treatments led to lower PANSS total scores (P < 0.05).  

- üìä The improvements extended to cognitive function as measured by the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), showing higher scores for patients treated with magnesium valproate and lamotrigine when compared to those on olanzapine.

- After three months, the proportion of patients achieving a modified Rankin scale score of 0-1, indicative of good functional outcomes, was significantly higher in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups (P < 0.05).

Input:
Olanzapine vs. magnesium valproate vs. lamotrigine in anti-N-methyl-D-aspartic acid receptor encephalitis: a retrospective study

Abstract
--------

### Background

This study aimed to compare the impact of olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine as adjunctive treatments for anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) encephalitis. And it is expected to add supporting points related to the rebalance of neurotransmitters in the brain through adjuvant therapy in the clinical management of anti-NMDAR encephalitis.

### Methods

This retrospective study included patients diagnosed with anti-NMDAR encephalitis who received standardized immunotherapy at Hunan Brain Hospital between January 2018 and December 2020.

### Results

Compared to the olanzapine group, both the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups showed lower scores on the positive and negative symptom scale (PANSS) total score after 3 weeks of treatment (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05). The Montreal Cognitive Assessment Scale (MoCA) scores in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups were significantly higher than in the olanzapine group after 3 weeks and 3 months of treatment (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05). After 3 months of treatment, the proportions of patients with a modified Rankin scale score (mRS) of 0‚Äì1 in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups were significantly higher than in the olanzapine group (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05). The electroencephalogram (EEG) abnormality ranks at 3 months were significantly lower in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups compared with the olanzapine group (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05). Furthermore, the Glx/Cr ratio significantly decreased after 3 months of treatment (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05) in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups, while the Glx/Cr ratio in the olanzapine group showed no significant change (_P_‚Äâ>‚Äâ0.05).

### Conclusion

Compared with olanzapine, the addition of magnesium valproate or lamotrigine to immunotherapy might be associated with a lower PANSS score, higher MoCA score, and lower mRS score. The improvement of neurological functions and cognitive function may be related to the decreased Glx/Cr ratio.

Introduction
------------

Anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) encephalitis is a rare autoimmune encephalitis with acute onset neuropsychiatric symptoms due to an autoimmune reaction to the glutamate N receptor (GluN1) subunit of the neuronal NMDAR. The reported annual incidence is about 1.5 per million persons-year. Currently, the recommended treatment for anti-NMDAR encephalitis is the use of first-line immunotherapy that includes glucocorticoids, Œ≥-globulin, plasma exchange, tumor resection, acyclovir (until a viral etiology is ruled out), and symptomatic support. Still, only about 53% of patients appear to respond well to first-line immunotherapy, with a fairly high recurrence rate. Pathogenically, the autoantibody binds to the extracellular domain of the GluN1 subunit, resulting in NMDAR internalization and glutamatergic hypofunction. The first-line immunotherapies appear to intervene at the antigen/antibody reaction stage, which might underscore the limited effectiveness of this treatment strategy in the context of potentially broader pathophysiological alterations in the brain.

Given the existence of glutamatergic hypofunction in anti-NMDAR encephalitis, it can be hypothesized that an imbalance of excitatory/inhibitory neurotransmission should be present in the brain, contributing to the pathophysiology of the disease. Accordingly, adjuvant therapies that help mitigate this imbalance could be beneficial in the clinical management of patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis. A case report suggested using adjuvant memantine to manage catatonia in anti-NMDAR encephalitis. Ketamine can also be used in patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis and refractory persistent epilepsy. Intrathecal methotrexate has been suggested for refractory anti-NMDAR encephalitis. Still, few data are available regarding adjuvant therapies in anti-NMDAR encephalitis.

Therefore, this retrospective study aimed to compare the cognitive and neurological functions of three adjuvant drugs in treating anti-NMDAR encephalitis, and to establish a relationship between these improvements and the balance in neuronal excitation and inhibition through glutamate (Glu) and Œ≥-aminobutyric acid (GABA). Based on this study, we hypothesized that the effects of three adjunctive therapeutics in the treatment of anti-NMDAR encephalitis were determined by relating their clinical efficacy for the improvement of cognitive and neurological functions to their extent of pharmacological modulation of glutamate (Glu) and Œ≥-aminobutyric acid (GABA) transmission in the cerebrum.

Materials and methods
---------------------

### Study design and patients

This retrospective study collected the clinical data of patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis admitted to Hunan Brain Hospital between January 2018 and December 2020. All included patients received standard immunotherapy and different adjuvant treatments. The patients were then grouped based on the adjuvant medications they received.

The study was approved by the Medical Ethics Committee of Hunan Brain Hospital (approval #2018K065). The requirement for informed consent was waived by the committee because of the retrospective nature of the study. All data were anonymized after extraction and before analysis.

### Inclusion and exclusion criteria

Clinical cases meeting the diagnostic criteria for anti-NMDAR encephalitis according to clinical guidelines. The exclusion criteria included encephalitis with other causes, tumors found, seizures as the first symptom, and incomplete clinical data.

### Drug administration

All patients receive standardized first-line immunotherapy after admission, including intravenous immunoglobulin injection (According to the patient‚Äôs weight, a total of 2 g/kg should be administered intravenously for three to five days.), plasma exchange (with a dose of 1.0 to 1.5 times the total plasma volume, performed 3‚Äì6 exchanges within 10‚Äì14 days.), glucocorticoids (methylprednisolone 1000 mg/d for 3 consecutive days, 500 mg/d for 3 consecutive days, followed by a reduction of 40-80 mg/d.). According to the 2017 Consensus of Chinese Experts on the Diagnosis and Treatment of Autoimmune Encephalitis, doctors choose different drugs for adjuvant treatment based on the different clinical symptoms of patients.

### Outcomes and data collection

The primary outcome was improving the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS), the Montreal Cognitive Assessment Scale (MoCA), and the modified Rankin Scale (mRS). As per routine practice, all patients underwent assessments using the PANSS, the MoCA, and the mRS before initiating any treatment. The PANSS and the MoCA were conducted at 3 weeks and 3 months after the initial treatments. The mRS were assessed at 3 months after the start of treatments. The PANSS quantifies positive symptoms (which refer to excess or distortion of normal functions, e.g., hallucinations and delusions) and negative symptoms (which represent a diminution or loss of normal functions) and is widely used in the study of psychopharmacologic therapy. Each subscale is scored 1‚Äì7 points ranging from absent to extreme. The range for the positive and negative scales is 7‚Äì49, and the range for the general psychopathology scale is 16‚Äì112. The MoCA is a test used to detect mild cognitive decline and early signs of dementia. It contains 11 tests in eight cognitive areas: attention and concentration, executive function, memory, language, visual structure skills, abstract thinking, computation, and orientation. The total score is 30, and _‚â•_‚Äâ26 is considered normal. The mRS is originally developed to evaluate the state of neurological recovery in patients after stroke, and it has been extended used to various neurological conditions, including autoimmune encephalitis. The mRS scores are categorized as follows: 0: no symptoms; 1: no significant disability and able to carry out all usual activities; 2: slight disability; 3: moderate disability; 4: moderately severe disability; 5: severe disability; 6: death. Generally, mRS scores of 0‚Äì1 indicate a good functional prognosis. The above experimental scales were evaluated by two residents of the psychiatric department of this hospital.

The secondary outcomes were magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), electroencephalogram (EEG), and antibody titer changes. The above experimental scales were evaluated by two Imaging doctors and electroencephalography doctors.

All patients underwent EEG assessments before initiating any treatment, as well as at 3 weeks and 3 months after the start of the treatments. The EEGs were rated as normal, mild, moderate, or severe. The EEG records from the patients were scored as the frequency (n) of ‚Äúnormal and mild background abnormalities (No‚Äâ+‚ÄâMi)‚Äù or ‚Äúmoderate background and severe background abnormalities (Mo‚Äâ+‚ÄâSe)‚Äù. The improvement rate of EEG was defined as (No‚Äâ+‚ÄâMi)/total number of patients √ó100%. The patients underwent magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) before treatment and 3 months after treatment. The powers of the neurotransmitters Glu and GABA were determined by brain fluctuation mapping, with the Glx/Cr index measured at the top of the left frontal lobe in each patient. The reference powers of Glu and GABA in the brain were determined by Shenzhen Kangli High Tech Co., Ltd. after testing 10,000 healthy people nationwide and were 38.36‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ12.91 for Glu and 31.67‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ13.93 for GABA. In order to further explore the influence of drug treatment on the excitatory/inhibitory homeostasis of the brain, the resonance peaks of Glx (contributed by glutamate, glutamine, and GABA together) and Cr (contributed largely by GABA) were obtained at the top of the left frontal lobe by MRS, with the Glx/Cr ratio calculated for each patient before treatment and three months after treatment.

Demographic data were collected from the medical records of included patients, including age, sex, disease course, time of drug initiation and clinical symptoms.

### Statistical analysis

### Sample size

the retrospective nature of the study predetermines the sample size. A priori sample size calculation was not performed.

All analyses were performed using SPSS 25.0 (IBM, Armonk, NY, USA). The continuous data were tested for normal distribution using the Shapiro-Wilk test. Continuous data with a normal distribution were represented as means‚Äâ¬±‚Äâstandard deviations and analyzed using ANOVA and the LSD-t post hoc test. Continuous data with a non-normal distribution were presented as medians (ranges) and analyzed using the Kruskal-Wallis H-test. Paired sample _t_-test signed rank sum test was used to compare before and after treatment. Categorical data were presented using n (%) and analyzed using the chi-squared test or Fisher‚Äôs exact test. Two-sided P-values‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05 were considered statistically significant. The graphs were prepared using GraphPad Prism 7.0 (GraphPad Software Inc., San Diego, CA, USA).

Results
-------

According to the inclusion criteria, 97 patients with anti NMDAR encephalitis were included, 2 patients with concomitant tumors were excluded, and 5 patients with incomplete clinical data were excluded. Finally, 90 patients with anti NMDAR encephalitis were enrolled. Patients were grouped according to the adjuvant medications they received: group A (olanzapine group, _n_‚Äâ=‚Äâ36), group B (magnesium valproate group, _n_‚Äâ=‚Äâ30) and group C (lamotrigine group, _n_‚Äâ=‚Äâ24).

### Characteristics of the patients

Ninety patients were included in the study. The olanzapine group consisted of 24 males and 12 females. The patients were 28.50‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ9.29 years old. The median disease course was 9.5 (4.00, 29.05) days. The time to drug initiation was 0 (0, 1) days. The magnesium valproate group included 17 males and 13 females. The patients were 29.97‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ11.71 years old. The disease course was 10 (5, 20) days. The time to drug initiation was 0 (0, 2) days. The lamotrigine group included 13 males and 11 females. They were 33.88‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ9.59 years old. The disease course was 10 (6.25, 17.25) days. The time to drug initiation was 0 (1, 3) days. There were no significant differences in the above indicators among the three groups (all _P_‚Äâ>‚Äâ0.05). There were no significant differences in cognitive impairment, motor impairment, speech impairment, autonomic dysfunction, seizures, and decreased consciousness among the three groups before any treatment (all _P_‚Äâ>‚Äâ0.05).

### Psychiatric symptoms

Before treatment, there were no significant differences in total PANSS scores, positive symptom scores, negative symptom scores, and general psychopathological scores among the three groups (all _P_‚Äâ>‚Äâ0.05). After 3 weeks of treatment, the PANSS total score and positive symptom scores in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups were lower than in the olanzapine group (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05). The general psychopathological scores in the magnesium valproate group were lower than in the olanzapine and lamotrigine groups after 3 weeks of treatment (_P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05). After 3 months of treatment, the PANSS total and negative symptom scores in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups were lower than in the olanzapine group (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05).

### Cognitive functions

Among the 90 patients, 22 had missing data regarding the MoCA scores, and a total of 68 patients were included in the evaluation of cognitive performance. Among them, 26 patients were in the olanzapine group, 23 were in the magnesium valproate group, and 19 were in the lamotrigine group. Before treatment, the MoCA scores were 21.35‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ3.76, 22.39‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ4.30, and 22.26‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ4.37 in the olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine groups, respectively (_P_‚Äâ>‚Äâ0.05). After 3 months of treatment, the MoCA scores in the olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine groups were improved compared with baseline (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05). Notably, after 3 weeks and 3 months of treatment, the scores in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups were higher than in the olanzapine group (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05).

### Functional status of the patients

There were no significant differences in the mRS score among the olanzapine group (0/36, mRS score 0‚Äì1/mRS score‚Äâ‚â•‚Äâ2), the magnesium valproate group (0/30), and the lamotrigine group (0/24) before treatment (all _P_‚Äâ>‚Äâ0.05). After 3 months of treatment, the proportions of patients with an mRS score 0‚Äì1 in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups were significantly higher than in the olanzapine group (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05).

### EEG characteristics

Before treatment, the EEG ranks were 7/29 (No‚Äâ+‚ÄâMi/Mo‚Äâ+‚ÄâSe) in the olanzapine group, 7/23 in the magnesium valproate group, and 5/19 in the lamotrigine group. There were no significant differences among the three groups (_P_‚Äâ>‚Äâ0.05). After 3 weeks and 3 months of treatment, the EEG ranks were as follows: 10/26 after 3 weeks and 18/18 after 3 months in the olanzapine group, 11/19 after 3 weeks, and 24/6 after 3 months in the magnesium valproate group, 12/12 after 3 weeks and 21/3 after 3 months in the olanzapine group. There was a significant improvement in the EEG characteristics after 3 weeks and 3 months of treatment (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05). The abnormality EEG ranks at 3 months were significantly lower in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups compared with the olanzapine group (all _P_‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05).

### Excitatory/inhibitory rebalance

Compared with the reference range for healthy people, the Glu powers (294.41‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ160.09, 300.55‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ205.34, and 314.46‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ224.11 for the olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine groups, respectively) were increased significantly, and the GABA powers (6.31‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ5.04, 5.92‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ4.68, and 5.26‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ4.98 for the olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine groups, respectively) were decreased significantly in all three groups before treatment, while no intergroup difference existed at this point. The olanzapine group showed no significant alterations in Glu and GABA power after 3 months of treatment. Compared with the olanzapine group, the power of Glu was significantly decreased after treatment in the magnesium valproate group, whereas the power of GABA was significantly elevated after treatment. Similarly, compared with the olanzapine group, the power of Glu was decreased, and the power of GABA was increased after treatment in the lamotrigine group.

### Cerebral Glx/Cr ratio measured by MRS

The Glx/Cr ratios before treatment were 0.35‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ0.24, 0.30‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ0.10, and 0.28‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ0.20 for the olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine groups, respectively (_P_‚Äâ>‚Äâ0.05). After 3 months of treatment, the Glx/Cr ratio in the olanzapine group remained comparable to the pre-treatment levels. However, in the magnesium valproate group, the Glx/Cr ratio significantly decreased, and in the lamotrigine group, it decreased compared to the pre-treatment levels. Furthermore, the Glx/Cr ratios obtained after 3 months of treatment were significantly lower in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups compared to the olanzapine group.

Discussion
----------

The findings of this study indicate that the addition of magnesium valproate or lamotrigine to immunotherapy might be associated with lower PANSS scores and higher MoCA scores compared to olanzapine. It has been observed that patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis show an imbalance between glutamatergic and GABAergic neurotransmission in the brain. The beneficial effects of magnesium valproate and lamotrigine appear to be associated with restoring the balance between excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain.

In patients with anti NMDAR encephalitis, the incidence of epileptic seizures is second only to mental disorders, consistent with previous reports. Other clinical symptoms in the present study included cognitive impairment, autonomic nerve dysfunction, decreased level of consciousness, dyskinesia, and speech disorder, also consistent with clinical characteristics reported in previous studies.

Immunotherapy is the gold standard in the clinical management of anti-NMDAR encephalitis. Because the disease often presents with broad and complex neurological and psychiatric symptoms, other central nervous system medicines can be used for anti-NMDAR encephalitis. Along with the mainstay immunotherapy, adjuvant pharmacological intervention to facilitate the homeostasis of neurotransmission in the brain could be beneficial in the clinical management of anti-NMDAR encephalitis by managing specific symptoms related to the imbalance described above.

Olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine are commonly used antipsychotics in the treatment of schizophrenia, epilepsy, bipolar disorder, and other psychiatric diseases. Although their specific use in anti-NMDAR encephalitis carries little evidence, they can be used to manage psychiatric symptoms. Compared with olanzapine, magnesium valproate and lamotrigine led to lower scores on the PANSS total score and positive symptom scores after 3 weeks of treatment. The MoCA scores were significantly higher with magnesium valproate and lamotrigine than with olanzapine. The proportions of patients with good clinical outcomes of mRS scores in the magnesium valproate and lamotrigine groups were greater than in the olanzapine group after 3 months of treatment.

Olanzapine is a second-generation antipsychotic agent and exhibits high affinity to many neuroactive receptors, such as serotonin, dopamine Œ±-adrenaline, and histamine, with limited influence on the glutamatergic pathway. Limited evidence (mostly case reports) supports using olanzapine in anti-NMDAR encephalitis, with some effectiveness. Valproate is approved for manic or mixed episodes associated with bipolar disorder or for the prevention of migraine headaches; it can competitively inhibit GABA transferase and reduce its metabolism to increase the content of GABA in the brain, which may, in turn, inhibit glutamatergic neurons and reduce glutamate release. The evidence for valproate using in anti-NMDAR encephalitis is also limited but appears favorable, but the use of valproate before an anti-NMDAR encephalitis diagnosis could possibly interfere with the diagnosis. Lamotrigine mainly blocks glutamate release from the presynaptic membrane, inhibiting the excitatory action potential mediated by glutamate and managing seizures. Although lamotrigine has been reported to control the seizures associated with anti-NMDAR encephalitis, the evidence is limited. Previous evidence suggested that the dysfunction of the glutamatergic pathway is related to the epileptic symptoms of anti-NMDAR encephalitis.

However, the mechanism by which NMDAR down-regulation causes complex clinical symptoms in patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis remains incompletely understood. Some studies have proposed that besides NMDAR down-regulation and resulting glutamatergic hypofunction, an imbalance of excitatory/inhibitory neurotransmission may be involved in the pathogenesis and clinical manifestations among patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis. Accordingly, the present study showed that such imbalances exist based on the Glu, GABA, and Glx/Cr ratio obtained by MRS and compared with reference values obtained from 10,000 healthy individuals in China.

Based on their neuropharmacological characteristics, this study evaluated the clinical benefits of adjuvant administration of olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine in anti-NMDAR encephalitis, particularly about their capability of facilitating the rebalance of excitatory/inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain. Olanzapine treatment did not alter the Glu and GABA powers in the brain, nor the cortical Glx/Cr ratio, which is consistent with the notion that this drug does not modulate the glutamate system in the brain. On the contrary, adjuvant magnesium valproate lowered the Glu power and the Glx/Cr ratio and elevated GABA power in the cerebrum. Similarly, lamotrigine treatment reduced the power of Glu and Glx/Cr ratio but increased the power of GABA in the brain. Importantly, these above differential neurochemical modulations by the three drugs are associated with measurable differences regarding neurological recovery. Thus, compared with olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine showed better therapeutical effects, as indicated by the assessments on the extent of mitigation of mental symptoms, improvement of cognitive function, better functional outcome, and normalization of EEG features in patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis.

This study had limitations. It was performed at a single hospital and included patients diagnosed over a limited period, resulting in a relatively small sample size. The retrospective nature of the study limited the data that could be analyzed to the ones available in the patient charts. No control group of patients treated with immunotherapy could be included because most patients received adjuvant treatments during the study period. Additional studies with other adjuvant drugs, such as memantine, ketamine, and intrathecal methotrexate, should be carried out to determine the most optimal adjuvant treatments and determine whether specific subgroups of patients could benefit more from a given drug.

Conclusion
----------

This study shows that based on standard immunotherapy, adjuvant therapeutics aiming to correct the cerebral Glu/GABA or excitatory/inhibitory imbalance, such as valproate and lamotrigine, can improve the clinical outcome among patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis.

Data availability
-----------------

All data generated or analysed during this study are included in this published article.

- Notably, this risk heightened with each incremental increase in ultra-processed food intake, suggesting a direct correlation worth considering in dietary advice. 
- Inflammatory markers, lipids, and liver enzymes accounted for up to 14.8% of this association, emphasizing the biological pathway connecting diet with autoimmune conditions. 

As we continue to explore dietary influences in clinical practice, it‚Äôs critical to advocate for reduced ultra-processed food consumption. With nearly HALF of food intake in the UK classified as ultra-processed, integrating these findings into guidelines could be pivotal in RA prevention strategies. 

What changes can we implement in dietary counseling to prioritize whole foods over ultra-processed options for our patients?  ü§î

Input:
Rheumatoid Arthritis: Whole-Food Diet May Be Protective
===============
                                      

This site is intended for UK healthcare professionals

*   Recent Searches [Clear](http://medscape.co.uk/viewarticle/rheumatoid-arthritis-whole-food-diet-may-be-protective-2024a1000g29#)

Clinical Summary

Rheumatoid Arthritis: Whole-Food Diet May Be Protective
=======================================================

Susan London

TOPLINE:
--------

Middle-aged adults who consume more ultra-processed foods have an elevated risk for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) that is mediated in part through circulating biomarkers.

METHODOLOGY:¬†
-------------

*   Investigators conducted a retrospective cohort study of 207,012 middle-aged adults without RA from the UK Biobank who completed 24-hour dietary recalls.
*   Foods and beverages were classified as (1) unprocessed or minimally processed foods, (2) processed culinary ingredients, (3) processed foods, or (4) ultra-processed foods (eg, soft drinks, sweet or savoury packaged snacks, reconstituted meat products, pre-prepared frozen dishes).
*   The main outcome was the incident RA based on hospital diagnoses.

TAKEAWAY:
---------

*   Overall, 0.9% of participants received an RA diagnosis during a median follow-up of about 12 years.
*   Relative to peers in the lowest quintile of ultra-processed food consumption, participants in the highest quintile had a 17% greater adjusted risk for RA.
*   The risk rose across quintile (P < .05) and increased by 6% with each standard deviation increase in ultra-processed food intake.
*   Mediation analyses suggested that inflammatory, lipid, and liver enzyme biomarkers explained 3.1%-14.8% of the association between ultra-processed food intake and RA risk.
*   Findings were similar regardless of participants' age, sex, body mass index, smoking status, household income, and healthy diet score.

IN PRACTICE:¬†
-------------

"Lower [ultra-processed food] consumption is recommended to reduce RA incidence," the authors wrote, noting that up to half of the food consumed in the United Kingdom now falls into the ultra-processed category. "Dietary guidelines should prominently feature the detrimental effects of [ultra-processed foods], and recommendations to curtail their consumption should be integrated into public health initiatives, to mitigate the risk of RA," they added.

SOURCE:
-------

The study was led by Haodong Zhao, Soochow University, Suzhou, China, and was published online in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition.

LIMITATIONS:
------------

Limitations included possible recall and social desirability biases, potential residual confounding, and uncertain causality of the observed associations.

DISCLOSURES:
------------

The study was funded by grants from the National Natural Science Foundation of China and other institutions. The authors reported no conflicts of interest.

- KEY SESSIONS: 
   - DR. JULIE OLIVER will introduce new British Menopause Society guidelines on managing unscheduled bleeding with HRT, providing a practical flowchart to aid decision-making and risk stratification.
   - DR. CAROLINE COOPER will present updated contraceptive options tailored for women over 40, emphasizing an individualised approach to care.
   - DR. ANGELA WRIGHT will broaden the discussion to younger women, addressing the role of testosterone in managing libido alongside menopause issues.

It's crucial to stay informed on these critical updates in women's health. With the ongoing debates about access to HRT and the importance of women's perspectives in healthcare policies, such sessions are vital for enhancing our clinical practices.

ü§î How are you currently addressing women‚Äôs health issues in your practice? Let's share strategies for improvement!

Discover more about these initiatives and register for Guidelines Live 2024 here: https://www.guidelineslive.co.uk/ 

#WomenHealth #HRT #GuidelinesLive #PrimaryCare

Join Dr Julie Oliver and the Primary Care Women‚Äôs Health Forum at Guidelines Live 2024
===============

This site is intended for UK healthcare professionals

Welcome to the new home of Guidelines in Practice

Browse our expert articles to support best practice for UK healthcare professionals.

For Primary Care | Hot topic

Join Dr Julie Oliver and the Primary Care Women‚Äôs Health Forum at _Guidelines Live_ 2024
========================================================================================

Primary Care Women's Health Forum

**In Anticipation of** _**Guidelines Live**_ **2024, the PCWHF Provides a Taster of its Sessions in the Women‚Äôs Health Stream, Which Will Address Key Issues Around Menopause and HRT**

A PCWHF session at _Guidelines Live_ 2023

The Primary Care Women‚Äôs Health Forum (PCWHF) is excited to return to _Guidelines Live_ in 2024, following its success delivering presentations to full lecture theatres in 2023. This year, PCWHF speaker sessions will have a primary-care relevant, practical focus, underpinned by realistic case studies to illustrate the application of guidelines in the real world.

Published in 2022, the _Women‚Äôs Health Strategy for England_ notes that there is not enough focus on women-specific issues such as menopause. Over the past few years, healthcare professionals have faced challenges such as shortages of hormone-replacement therapy (HRT), a lack of licensed options for testosterone as part of HRT, and funding for the fitting of intrauterine devices and implants that may not cover the costs of the procedure.

In the first of the PCWHF speaker sessions on Day 1, **Dr Julie Oliver**, PCWHF Chair, will discuss the recent British Menopause Society guideline on the management of unscheduled bleeding in women taking HRT. The guideline provides a new approach to risk stratification, and includes a helpful one-page summary flowchart to guide management. It also answers the perennial question ‚Äò_How high is too high?_‚Äô‚Äîthat is, what is the oestrogen dose needed to increase the amount of progestogen in an HRT regime? Dr Oliver is an NHS GP in County Durham, with an extended role in women‚Äôs health and a long history of speaking at conferences such as _Guidelines Live_.

On the Day 2 of _Guidelines Live_ 2024, **Dr Caroline Cooper** will give a contraception update, with a focus on new guidance. Dr Cooper will explore contraceptive options for women over 40 years of age, emphasising safety, efficacy, and individualised care approaches. Dr Cooper is an experienced GP with an extended role in women‚Äôs health. She is also a faculty-registered trainer, and has served on the Faculty of Sexual & Reproductive Healthcare committees, as well as being a current director of the PCWHF.

Next, **Dr Angela Wright** will continue the HRT theme, but adding relevance to younger women, by discussing testosterone and libido. Informed by her experience of primary and secondary care NHS work, Dr Wright‚Äôs speaker session will explain how those in primary care can support women who have complex menopause issues, sexual dysfunction, and premenstrual disorders. Dr Wright is a fellow of the European Committee of Sexual Medicine, and an active committee member of the British Society of Sexual Medicine.

### The Primary Care Women‚Äôs Health Forum

These _Guidelines Live_ sessions are supported by the Primary Care Women‚Äôs Health Forum (PCWHF), a group of 10,000 healthcare professionals with a special interest in women‚Äôs health. The PCWHF aims to promote and progress standards in women‚Äôs health in primary care through education, resources, and events, and lobbies on behalf of its members to determine future strategic direction and policymaking for women‚Äôs health. [Find out more about the PCWHF](https://pcwhf.co.uk/).

For more information on _Guidelines Live_ 2024, click [here](https://www.guidelineslive.co.uk/).  

In 2024, _Guidelines Live_ will take place on Tuesday 19 and Wednesday 20 November at ExCeL London‚Äîto dedicate 2 days to your learning and development, [book now](https://eventdata.uk/Forms/Form.aspx?FormRef=GuiB4Visitor) at the summer offer rate of only ¬£49.  

_Guidelines Live_ is an educational event made possible by sponsorship from organisations including pharmaceutical companies. Sponsors have had no input into the agenda of the meeting unless through sponsored session(s) as indicated on the main programme.

Note: Some of the issues discussed in this article only affect those of the female sex and so the terms woman/women and the pronouns she/her have been used throughout this article. Sensitivity should be used when your patient‚Äôs gender does not match their biological sex, including using the patient‚Äôs preferred pronouns.

Note: At the time of publication (September 2024), some of the treatments discussed in this article did not have UK marketing authorisation for the indications discussed. Prescribers should refer to the individual summaries of product characteristics for further information and recommendations regarding the use of pharmacological therapies. For off-licence use of medicines, the prescriber should follow relevant professional guidance, taking full responsibility for the decision. Informed consent should be obtained and documented. See the General Medical Council‚Äôs [_Good practice in prescribing and managing medicines and devices_](https://www.gmc-uk.org/ethical-guidance/ethical-guidance-for-doctors/good-practice-in-prescribing-and-managing-medicines-and-devices) for further information.
